abstract: The offer for Russia’s biggest wholesale power producer comes from Dubai World and OAO Roskommunenergo, an energy trading company headed by the son of the Kremlin’s top real estate official.
snippet: The offer for Russia’s biggest wholesale power producer comes from Dubai World and OAO Roskommunenergo, an energy trading company headed by the son of the Kremlin’s top real estate official.
lead_paragraph: Dubai World, the state-owned investment group, and OAO Roskommunenergo, an energy trading company headed by the son of the Kremlin’s top real estate official, offered to buy Russia’s biggest wholesale power producer for $5.34 billion before price caps end in 2011. The acquisition by Dubai World, which has more than $100 billion in assets ranging from ports to hotels, would be the first in Russia’s energy industry by a Persian Gulf investor. Roskommunenergo, formed in 2004, is led by Igor Kozhin, the son of Vladimir Kozhin, who has run the Kremlin’s property department since 2000, when he was appointed by Vladimir Putin. They are offering to buy OGK-1 as state-run OAO Unified Energy System, which has raised $34 billion selling generation and distribution assets since 2006, ceases to exist on Tuesday amid a government drive to deregulate the power industry after 10 years of economic growth. OGK-1, which operates four plants in European Russia and two in Siberia, supplies electricity to Moscow and the oil-rich Tyumen region where expansion has increased demand.

headline.main: Russia: $5.3. Billion Bid for Energy Company
headline.print_headline: Russia: $5.3. Billion Bid For Energy Company

abstract: Lawyers for the Bank of New York Mellon were in a Russian court to defend the bank against a $22.5 billion claim filed by the Russian customs service relating to a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s.
snippet: Lawyers for the Bank of New York Mellon were in a Russian court to defend the bank against a $22.5 billion claim filed by the Russian customs service relating to a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Bank of New York Mellon were in a Russian court to defend the bank against a $22.5 billion claim filed by the Russian customs service relating to a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s. Under a novel legal theory, a group of Miami lawyers working on a contingency basis has taken the case for the customs service and argued that the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act should be applied in Russia. The bank said the United States law cannot be applied by a Russian court, that the money transfers did not amount to a crime covered by the act and that the damage claim is not supported by evidence. The bank flew a former attorney general, Richard Thornburgh, above, to Moscow to make the arguments as an expert witness. The judge, however, Lyudmila Pulova, postponed the hearing before he could testify. The next hearing is Thursday; Mr. Thornburgh was scheduled to leave Moscow on Wednesday. The bank has not set aside reserves against an adverse judgment, saying the Russian court ruling will in any case not be enforceable in the United States.

headline.main: Russia: Bank of New York Fights $22.5. Billion Claim
headline.print_headline: Russia: Bank of New York Fights $22.5. Billion Claim

abstract: India banned corn exports and curbed shipments of steel, seeking to increase domestic supplies and cool the fastest inflation in 13 years as world commodity prices soar.
snippet: India banned corn exports and curbed shipments of steel, seeking to increase domestic supplies and cool the fastest inflation in 13 years as world commodity prices soar.
lead_paragraph: India banned corn exports and curbed shipments of steel, seeking to increase domestic supplies and cool the fastest inflation in 13 years as world commodity prices soar. India’s corn ban adds to curbs on exports of rice, wheat and cooking oil as the government seeks to tame price increases that have driven interest rates to a six-year high. The nation increased corn shipments more than sixfold in the last year as the global price doubled. Shipments from India totaled a record 2.5 million tons in the year that ended June 30 as feed makers in Southeast Asia sought cheaper alternatives to supplies from the United States. Exports were 400,000 tons in the previous year.

headline.main: India Curbs Corn and Steel Exports

abstract: Britain’s services sector contracted last month by the most since October 2001 and banks said they would curb lending further in the third quarter.
snippet: Britain’s services sector contracted last month by the most since October 2001 and banks said they would curb lending further in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s services sector contracted last month by the most since October 2001 and banks said they would curb lending further in the third quarter. An index based on sales and business conditions at about 700 service companies fell to 47.1 in June from 49.8 a month earlier, the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said. A reading below 50 shows contraction. “The figures are really bad news,” said Alex Garatti, British economist for Natixis, after the services figures were released. “It shows the U.K. is really suffering from tightening financial conditions and the slowdown in housing.” A separate Bank of England survey showed that banks planned to reduce the availability of credit to consumers and businesses this quarter.

headline.main: Britain’s Services Sector Contracted in June

lead_paragraph: European Union regulators extended an investigation into BHP Billiton’s hostile bid for the Rio Tinto Group because of “serious doubts” about the combination, which would control more than a third of the world’s iron ore production. The European Commission, in charge of antitrust rulings, will review the proposed $163 billion acquisition for an additional 90 working days and announce a decision by Nov. 11, it said in a statement in Brussels on Friday. The antitrust division of the United States Justice Department gave partial approval Thursday. The takeover also needs agreement from Australia and South Africa.

abstract: A European Parliament committee voted to give national regulators the power to force dominant telephone companies to open their networks.
snippet: A European Parliament committee voted to give national regulators the power to force dominant telephone companies to open their networks.
lead_paragraph: A European Parliament committee voted to give national regulators the power to force dominant telephone companies like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom to open their networks, saying the proposal would help competition. The legislation, proposed last year by a European Telecommunications commissioner, Viviane Reding, will allow regulators in the 27-member European Union to split the high-speed networks and telephone services of dominant phone companies into separate units. Telecommunications companies have opposed the legislation, which requires approval from the entire European Parliament and national governments to become law, warning that it risks of harming investments in new fiber-optic networks and does not bolster competition.

headline.main: Measure to Open Networks Advances

abstract: Stock in Embraer rose the most in more than eight months as the company overcame production problems and increased second-quarter deliveries by 44 percent.
snippet: Stock in Embraer rose the most in more than eight months as the company overcame production problems and increased second-quarter deliveries by 44 percent.
lead_paragraph: Stock in Empresa Brasileira de Aeronáutica, the aircraft maker, rose the most in more than eight months as the company overcame production problems and increased second-quarter deliveries by 44 percent. Fifty-two planes were shipped from April through June, compared with 36 a year earlier, the company said. Embraer, as the company is known, reiterated plans to deliver as many as 215 jets this year. Production bottlenecks slowed deliveries in late 2006 and in early 2007. Embraer remedied the problem by replacing suppliers, adding about 4,500 workers and purchasing more machinery. Demand for its Phenom business jets helped its backlog climb to a record $20.7 billion. Its stock rose 4.8 percent.

headline.main: Brazil: Embraer Overcomes Bottleneck

abstract: Inspired by Benjamin Franklin’s Junto, two friends started the Silicon Valley Junto as a way to exchange ideas and network with their peers.
snippet: Inspired by Benjamin Franklin’s Junto, two friends started the Silicon Valley Junto as a way to exchange ideas and network with their peers.
lead_paragraph: When my friend and colleague Sarah Milstein wrote a guest post a few weeks ago about her idea of an urban hike, I received an amusing e-mail from a reader who said, “Wow, that’s like social networking in person.” Exactly. And in the age of online social networking, it is good to remember the value of face-to-face meetings. That brings me to today’s link, a powerful networking idea that owes its name to Benjamin Franklin, who cultivated and nurtured a thriving social network long before Web 2.0 co-opted the term.

headline.main: Friday’s Links: Networking Lessons from Ben Franklin

abstract: This just in from the Dept. of Unintended Consequences: among the many, many pieces of e-mail I received about my column about Google’s day-care woes last week were several from parents who had children in other day-care centers in Silicon Valley, particularly the small handful that use the Reggio Emilia philosophy. Apparently, when Google was preparing to open its ultra-fancy center, The Woods, it aggressively recruited Reggio Emilia-trained day-care teachers from all over the Bay Area. It lured them with much higher salaries and the prospect of being full-fledged Google employees — status that more than a few Google engineers can’t claim.

abstract: Hard to believe that with all its problems, the airline industry has the time to set up a Web site — and send out e-mail to just about everyone in America who has ever flown a plane — to complain about oil speculators. When I talked to the flack from the airline transport association, he basically blamed speculators for the cramped seats, the new charges for luggage, the foul meals, and just about everything else unpleasant about air travel. The cost of fuel this year, he added, is going to be more than $60 billion, compared to $40 billion-plus last year.

lead_paragraph: The chairman of Sony, Howard Stringer, left, said the company did not need to lower the price of the PlayStation 3 video game console in response to a possible $50 cut in the Microsoft’s Xbox 360. A price reduction by Microsoft would be evidence that the Xbox 360 was falling behind in the contest for sales, Mr. Stringer said Friday in an interview at the Allen & Company conference in Sun Valley, Idaho. Microsoft may lower the price of the Xbox 360 as soon as this weekend, The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday. Sales of the console in the United States lagged behind Nintendo’s Wii and the PlayStation 3 in the first five months of 2008, according to NPD Group, a market researcher.

headline.main: No Price Cuts Planned for Playstation 3
headline.print_headline: No Price Cuts Planned For Playstation 3

abstract: A new book explores the psychological forces that cause rational people to act in irrational ways.
snippet: A new book explores the psychological forces that cause rational people to act in irrational ways.
lead_paragraph: A new book, “Sway,” details the many ways that psychological forces can turn even the most logical thinker into an irrational, impulse-driven being. After reading “Sway” and having a series of conversations with its authors, I am suddenly questioning things. Am I right to believe a certain colleague is a star, or am I merely attributing characteristics to him based on his reputation? Am I sticking with a project long after I know it’s doomed for fear of accepting a loss? Have I been blind to a person’s talent because I am held sway by a first impression and interpret all facts in a way that supports that mistaken impression?

headline.main: Under the Sway of a New Book

abstract: So I hear through the grapevine that eBay’s executives are dancing in the street in the wake of the company’s victory in the Tiffany counterfeiting case. (Several years ago, Tiffany sued eBay for not proactively monitoring the site to prevent counterfeit items from being offered for sale or auction. One person involved in the case on the Tiffany side told me at the time that 95 percent of everything on eBay that was supposedly made by Tiffany was, in fact, fraudulent.) I hope they don’t party too hard at eBay not only because Tiffany is sure to appeal but also because it has lost three similar cases in Europe, brought by Rolex, Hermes and Louis Vuitton. No, the real problem here stems from eBay’s attitude toward its customers: namely, the site had no real responsibility toward rectifying wrongs — of any sort — that occur during an eBay transaction.
lead_paragraph: So I hear through the grapevine that eBay’s executives are dancing in the street in the wake of the company’s victory in the Tiffany counterfeiting case. (Several years ago, Tiffany sued eBay for not proactively monitoring the site to prevent counterfeit items from being offered for sale or auction. One person involved in the case on the Tiffany side told me at the time that 95 percent of everything on eBay that was supposedly made by Tiffany was, in fact, fraudulent.) I hope they don’t party too hard at eBay not only because Tiffany is sure to appeal but also because it has lost three similar cases in Europe, brought by Rolex, Hermes and Louis Vuitton. No, the real problem here stems from eBay’s attitude toward its customers: namely, the site had no real responsibility toward rectifying wrongs — of any sort — that occur during an eBay transaction.

headline.main: EBay’s Pyrrhic Victory

abstract: Thomas Daley, who runs an online barter site, is helping to lead a trend that has grown broadly over the past 25 years.

lead_paragraph: Thomas Daley had been helping friends swap sports tickets for golf course green fees and concert tickets as a sideline. But on the advice of a friend, he set up an online trading site, Joe Barter L.L.C., two years ago where college students could trade textbooks, small companies could trade equipment and accountants, and plumbers, business consultants and others could advertise their services.

In some versions, a submenu under the iTunes View menu gives you options for different patterns like “Lathe” or “Jelly.” With the regular iTunes Visualizer animations, tap the slash key to bring up an on-screen menu of other Visualizer key commands  such as pressing I to display the name of the song that is playing, or C to show the name of the current screen pattern.

abstract: Regular readers of my column–and I mean really regular readers — might recall that several years ago, I asked for nominations of good examples of business fiction written in the last 25 years. I promised to return to the subject in a future column once readers weighed in. This was a promise, alas, I failed to keep. Once I got the nominations, I bought many of the books, but there they sat, on the floor of my office, looking at me balefully for months, begging to be read. I just couldn’t do it. Doug Coupland’s brand of alienated-office-drone fiction didn’t move me.
lead_paragraph: Regular readers of my column–and I mean really regular readers — might recall that several years ago, I asked for nominations of good examples of business fiction written in the last 25 years. I promised to return to the subject in a future column once readers weighed in. This was a promise, alas, I failed to keep. Once I got the nominations, I bought many of the books, but there they sat, on the floor of my office, looking at me balefully for months, begging to be read. I just couldn’t do it. Doug Coupland’s brand of alienated-office-drone fiction didn’t move me.

headline.main: The Best Business Books Ever?

abstract: Is salary transparency a good thing for small companies — and for independent workers?
snippet: Is salary transparency a good thing for small companies — and for independent workers?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I went to hear Gloria Steinem speak. She said many memorable things, including this: If women were more willing to reveal their salaries to one another, they would make strides in eliminating the gender gap in wages. I think that’s true for all of us interested in boosting our earning potential. Of course, we all know what we’re worth to our employers or our investors by the amounts written on the checks they issue. But how many of us know what we are worth relative to others in the same or similar positions to us?

headline.main: Demystifying Salary Secrecy

abstract: The French government issued a decree allowing for the privatization of Gaz de France, enabling the utility to merge with Suez and form one of the largest utilities in the world.
snippet: The French government issued a decree allowing for the privatization of Gaz de France, enabling the utility to merge with Suez and form one of the largest utilities in the world.
lead_paragraph: The French government issued a decree allowing for the privatization of Gaz de France, enabling the utility to merge with Suez and form one of the largest utilities in the world. The new law allows for the transfer into the private sector of the majority stake held by the state in Gaz de France. Shareholders of Gaz de France and Suez approved the merger Wednesday, almost two and a half years after it was first announced by the French government. The move is scheduled to take effect July 22 when GDF Suez and Suez Environnement begin publicly trading. Some 65 percent of Suez Environnement is being spun off to existing Suez shareholders who own the unit.

headline.main: France: Gaz and Suez to Merge

lead_paragraph: The Barrick Gold Corporation, the world’s largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid. The all-cash offer of 410 million Canadian dollars ($409 million), or 6.75 Canadian dollars a share, was submitted to Cadence’s board, Barrick said. Barrick, based in Toronto, said on July 14 that it had proposed an all-cash offer of 354 million Canadian dollars. The competing bid came from Daylight Resources Trust, which offered 301 million Canadian dollars for Cadence on May 26. Cadence and Daylight Resources are both based in Calgary.

lead_paragraph: L’Oréal, the cosmetics maker, said 2008 sales would be lower than it projected after second-quarter growth was the slowest in more than three years. Sales in the three months ended June 30 increased 1 percent to 4.29 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.25 billion euros a year earlier as consumer spending faltered in the United States and Western Europe, the company said. Cosmetics sales fell 1.3 percent in Western Europe and 5.8 percent in North America. L’Oréal , based in Paris, forecast sales growth of more than 6 percent this year, a revision from its previous forecast of 6 to 8 percent.

lead_paragraph: Electrolux, the European appliance maker, reported second-quarter profit that missed analysts’ estimates and reduced its full-year earnings forecast after sales declined in the United States and Europe. Electrolux, based in Stockholm, said net income fell to 99 million kronor ($16.5 million) from 545 million kronor a year earlier on costs to close factories and upgrade products. lead_paragraph: OIL prices had their biggest ever drop this week, falling by more than $16 a barrel in the last four days. Still, oil remains at stratospheric levels, settling at $128.88 a barrel on Friday. And with global oil consumption still growing faster than new supplies, there are few remedies. In an interview, Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, shared his views on oil prices, the role of Western companies in a world increasingly dominated by state-owned energy giants and the future for alternative fuels in a fossil fuel world.

headline.main: Chief Says Exxon Will Keep Doing What It’s Doing

abstract: Google, whose business has been lagging on the Russian Internet, stepped up its business there with the $140 million purchase of a Cyrillic online advertising business on Friday.
snippet: Google, whose business has been lagging on the Russian Internet, stepped up its business there with the $140 million purchase of a Cyrillic online advertising business on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Google, whose business has been lagging on the Russian Internet, stepped up its business there with the $140 million purchase of a Cyrillic online advertising business on Friday. The deal also included a cooperation agreement with Rambler, one of Russia’s top search engines, to use Google’s ad placement technology on its site. Google’s managing director for emerging markets, Mohammad Gawat, said the deal showed his company’s commitment to fast-growing advertising markets like Russia. Anna Lepetukhhina, an Internet analyst at Troika Dialog, a Moscow brokerage firm, said Internet ad revenue was growing 30 to 40 percent a year in Russia.

headline.main: Google Buys Online Ad Business in Russia
headline.print_headline: Google Buys Online Ad Business In Russia

snippet: Honeywell International, the world’s largest maker of airplane instruments, said on Friday that second-quarter earnings rose 18 percent as it sold more cockpit displays and navigation systems.
lead_paragraph: Honeywell International, the world’s largest maker of airplane instruments, said on Friday that second-quarter earnings rose 18 percent as it sold more cockpit displays and navigation systems. Net income climbed to $723 million, or 96 cents a share, as sales rose 13 percent to $9.67 billion, the company said. Earnings and revenue beat analysts’ estimates, and the company said it would top its previous full-year forecasts for both measures. Honeywell raised its 2008 profit projection by 5 cents, to $3.75 to $3.85 a share, excluding gains from the pending sale of its aerospace fastener unit to BE Aerospace. The company stuck to its 2008 forecast for aerospace sales of $12.8 billion to $13 billion, despite concern about deferred orders from American airlines as they ground planes.

headline.main: Honeywell Raises 2008 Profit Forecast
headline.print_headline: Honeywell Raises 2008 Profit Forecast

abstract: The main advice I got from people who blog — as well as from people who know people who blog — is that I should be careful, lest it take over my life. Blogging has a way of doing that — you’re always looking at the new comments coming in, and posting them (so long as they aren’t ad hominem attacks on someone, or contain foul language, etc. etc.) And you’re always thinking of subjects you can blog about. And then you feel guilty if you’re not. I wanted to say something about Hector Ruiz being replaced as chief executive of AMD — as much as I like Ruiz and admire his rags-to-riches story, it sure looks like AMD has returned to taking two steps back for every one step forward, just as it always has. (Hmm…I guess I just posted after all!) I continue to want to mock the anti-short-selling mania in Washington and on Wall Street. I thought it was only the Chinese whose government tried to prop up falling stock prices. I guess not.
lead_paragraph: The main advice I got from people who blog — as well as from people who know people who blog — is that I should be careful, lest it take over my life. And then you feel guilty if you’re not. I wanted to say something about Hector Ruiz being replaced as chief executive of AMD — as much as I like Ruiz and admire his rags-to-riches story, it sure looks like AMD has returned to taking two steps back for every one step forward, just as it always has. (Hmm…I guess I just posted after all!) I continue to want to mock the anti-short-selling mania in Washington and on Wall Street. I thought it was only the Chinese whose government tried to prop up falling stock prices. I guess not.

headline.main: My Life as a Blogger, Week 1

abstract: Sos Cuetara, a Spanish bottler of olive oil, agreed to buy oil brands, including the market leaders Bertolli and Dante, from Unilever for 630 million euros ($1 billion).
snippet: Sos Cuetara, a Spanish bottler of olive oil, agreed to buy oil brands, including the market leaders Bertolli and Dante, from Unilever for 630 million euros ($1 billion).
lead_paragraph: Sos Cuetara, a Spanish bottler of olive oil, agreed to buy oil brands, including the market leaders Bertolli and Dante, from Unilever for 630 million euros ($1 billion). Sos Cuetara, based in Madrid, gains labels that have about one-third of their sales in the Americas as it tries to reduce dependence on Europe. Bertolli, founded in Tuscany in 1865, is the world’s biggest brand of olive oil, followed by Dante and Sos Cuetara’s Sasso, according to Unilever, which has headquarters in London and Rotterdam. The acquired assets generated 380 million euros in sales last year, compared with Sos Cuetara’s 1.4 billion euros of annual revenue.

lead_paragraph: Sanofi-Aventis, the French pharmaceuticals maker, agreed to buy Primary Health Care, the biggest distributor of vitamin supplements in Australia, for 560 million Australian dollars ($546 million). Sanofi, based in Paris, is seeking new sources of revenue before the Plavix and Lovenox anticlot treatments compete with cheaper copies, starting in 2011. Primary Health Care, based in Sydney, will use the funds to reduce debt tied to its takeover of Symbion Health in February and is part of a plan to sell consumer and pharmacy units acquired in that deal.

headline.main: Australia: Sanofi-Aventis Buys Vitamin Supplement Distributor

lead_paragraph: Jill Smart, an Accenture executive, was skeptical the first time she stepped into her firm’s new videoconferencing room in Chicago for a meeting with a group of colleagues in London. But the videoconferencing technology, known as telepresence, delivered an experience so lifelike, Ms. Smart recalled, that “10 minutes into it, you forget you are not in the room with them.”

headline.main: As Travel Costs Rise, More Meetings Go Virtual

abstract: The bid is for 39 Canadian dollars a share in cash, 21 percent higher than TransAlta’s last closing price, LS and Global said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
snippet: The bid is for 39 Canadian dollars a share in cash, 21 percent higher than TransAlta’s last closing price, LS and Global said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: LS Power Equity Partners and Global Infrastructure Partners offered to buy the TransAlta Corporation, Canada’s largest publicly traded electricity producer, for about 7.75 billion Canadian dollars ($7.72 billion) to tap growing energy demand in Alberta. The bid is for 39 Canadian dollars a share in cash, 21 percent higher than TransAlta’s last closing price, LS and Global said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The acquisition would take TransAlta private and leave its headquarters in Calgary. LS, a power-plant developer allied with Dynegy, owns about 9 percent of TransAlta’s stock, according to the filing. TransAlta said in a statement that it would review the proposal to discuss a buyout, made in a letter received Friday, and “respond in due course.” TransAlta’s holdings include coal, hydroelectric and wind-driven generators in Alberta.

headline.main: Canada: $7.72 Billion Bid for Electricity Producer

abstract: Looks Like Yahoo has figured out how to neuter Carl Icahn — kill him with kindness. That would seem to be the lesson emerging from Monday’s announcement that the 77-year-old shareholder activist, along with Jonathan Miller, who used to run Time Warner’s AOL division, will be joining the Yahoo board. It seems pretty likely that Icahn was about to lose his proxy fight — and that both he and Yahoo knew it. (It didn’t help Icahn that a big Yahoo shareholder Bill Miller of Legg Mason decided to side with Yahoo management, despite his annoyance that Yahoo didn’t sell to Microsoft.)

abstract: The Canadian Pacific Railway said second-quarter profit fell 40 percent and cut its full-year profit forecast as fuel costs rose and a slumping economy reduced traffic.
snippet: The Canadian Pacific Railway said second-quarter profit fell 40 percent and cut its full-year profit forecast as fuel costs rose and a slumping economy reduced traffic.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Pacific Railway said second-quarter profit fell 40 percent and cut its full-year profit forecast as fuel costs rose and a slumping economy reduced traffic. Net income fell to 154.9 million Canadian dollars ($154 million), from 256.7 million Canadian dollars, the company said. Sales rose less than 1 percent to 1.22 billion Canadian dollars. Canadian Pacific, based in Calgary, has been hurt by the economic slowdown in the United States, where it gets a fifth of its revenue. Automakers, builders and lumber companies are shipping less freight. The railroad also lost business because of flooding in the United States and an increase of 34 percent in its fuel costs. The quarter was “volatile,” the chief executive, Frederick J. Green, said in an interview. Mr. Green, above, said he did not expect a revival in the second half of the year, and the company forecast full-year earnings of 4 to 4.20 Canadian dollars a share, down from its earlier estimate of 4.40 to 4.60 Canadian dollars.

headline.main: Canada: Railway Posts Decline in Profit
headline.print_headline: CANADA: RAILWAY POSTS DECLINE IN PROFIT

lead_paragraph: United Steelworkers locals representing workers at three Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan mines have voted about 98 percent in favor of striking, the union said. The company is the world’s largest supplier of potash, a main ingredient in fertilizer, and controls about 22 percent market of the global market for the commodity, which has been rising in price. Workers at the mines have been without a contract since April and are seeking improvements in pay, benefits and pensions. Under Saskatchewan law, the union can call a strike on 48 hours notice, although it is continuing talks with the company. Workers at two other Saskatchewan mines owned by Potash are covered by union agreements with different expirations.

headline.main: Canada: Strike Vote at Potash Producer
headline.print_headline: CANADA: STRIKE VOTE AT POTASH PRODUCER

abstract: Goodmail Systems now has deals to pay most big Internet and Webmail providers to deliver messages from its clients without subjecting them to the dreaded spam filter. In return for first class delivery, Goodmail pays the e-mail companies a big part of its fees. Does this two-tier system violate the ideas of network neutrality?
snippet: Goodmail Systems now has deals to pay most big Internet and Webmail providers to deliver messages from its clients without subjecting them to the dreaded spam filter. In return for first class delivery, Goodmail pays the e-mail companies a big par...
lead_paragraph: Two years ago I wrote  about Goodmail Systems, a company that wants to help big companies make sure that e-mail they send doesn’t wind up trapped in a spam filter. Their idea is to charge the sender and give most of the money to the Internet providers and Web e-mail companies (like Google or Yahoo) to assure safe passage for paying messages.

headline.main: Goodmail Is Back Trying to Sell Access to Your In-Box

abstract: Call it junkware. Or bloatware or demoware or adware. It’s the software preinstalled on new Windows computers. In other words, marketers are using the computer you just bought as a billboard.
snippet: Call it junkware. Or bloatware or demoware or adware. It’s the software preinstalled on new Windows computers. In other words, marketers are using the computer you just bought as a billboard.
lead_paragraph: CALL it junkware. Or call it bloatware or demoware or adware. Computer users denounce it as crapware. It’s the software preinstalled on new Windows computers. (Bloatware is entirely a Windows issue; Macs don’t have such software.) It is there, usually in a trial version, to entice users to try a particular service or buy the full-featured program.

headline.main: Exorcise the Demons That Come Preinstalled

abstract: What Sam Zell has wrought at the Tribune Company.
snippet: What Sam Zell has wrought at the Tribune Company.
lead_paragraph: There are many, many reasons reporters at the Tribune Company newspapers feel that their new boss, Sam Zell, is in over his head. When he took over the Tribune — in a deal where he cleverly put the employees’ ESOP at risk, rather than his own fortune — he promised that he and his team would approach things differently, and would revive ad sales instead of cutting jobs. But he soon discovered what everyone else in the business already knew: ad sales are falling off the cliff, and no amount of wishful thinking can turn that around. So what did he do? He started laying off people — in some cases as much as 25 percent of the newsroom.

headline.main: AFDI!

abstract: Paul L. Kasriel of Northern Trust is one of my favorite economists because he looks at the facts. In this political season, we will see plenty of analysis by economists who have had, or want to have, government jobs. Somehow the analysis always seems to support the views of the people who gave them jobs, or will do so. It often reflects their ideology: This ought to happen, by the theory I believe. Therefore it does, and there is no need to look at real data.
lead_paragraph: Paul L. Kasriel of Northern Trust is one of my favorite economists because he looks at the facts. abstract: Matt Lauer, the “Today” show’s co-host since 1997, will team with Bob Costas to anchor the opening ceremony of the Summer Olympics from Beijing on Aug. 8.
snippet: Matt Lauer, the “Today” show’s co-host since 1997, will team with Bob Costas to anchor the opening ceremony of the Summer Olympics from Beijing on Aug. 8.
lead_paragraph: Matt Lauer, the “Today” show’s co-host since 1997, will team with Bob Costas to anchor the opening ceremony of the Summer Olympics from Beijing on Aug. 8, NBC is scheduled to announce on Monday. The prime time program, which includes the parade of nations, will occur in the morning in Beijing and be broadcast by NBC on tape.

headline.main: Olympics: Matt Lauer To Co-Anchor Opening Ceremony With Bob Costas

abstract: A federal judge has put the brakes on a lawsuit filed over sex scenes buried in the video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas.

abstract: As Americans’ appetite for gas-guzzlers has evaporated, General Motors may be closer to selling its Hummer brand, according to Reuters.

abstract: Which financial firms are primed to fare well as the markets continue to tremble? According to Fidelity Investments‘ flagship Magellan fund, they’re Goldman Sachs and the American International Group.

abstract: Corporate bond defaults are on track to quadruple this year and company bankruptcies may soar to more than 100 in 2009, a senior Bain & Company consultant told Reuters on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Corporate bond defaults are on track to quadruple this year and company bankruptcies may soar to more than 100 in 2009, a senior Bain & Company consultant told Reuters on Thursday.

headline.main: Bankruptcies May Skyrocket Next Year, Bain Executive Says
